Award.AwardTitle: Core Support for the Board on Life Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will continue support for core operations of the Board of Life Sciences (BLS) of the National Academy of Sciences. The BLS serves as the focal point for a wide range of technical and policy topics in the life sciences, including genomics, biodiversity conservation, bioterrorism, and key topics in basic biological and biomedical research, such as synthetic biology, the microbiome, and neuroscience. The BLS organizes and oversees studies that provide advice to government and the scientific community on the biological sciences and their impact on society. The BLS also oversees important studies on the improvement of biology education, particularly at the undergraduate level, and the maintenance of a robust life sciences workforce. More information can be found at: http://dels.nas.edu/bls/.

Support from this award will allow the BLS to: 1) hold one Board meeting per year, and 2) support staff time to develop topics for new studies and other projects and perform tasks related to completed studies. These functions are critical to the function and nature of the BLS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes

This document summarizes the work done by the Board on Life Sciences (BLS) over the performance period September 2016 through August 2019. BLS serves as the National Academies’ focal point for a wide range of technical and policy topics in the life sciences. In the study and workshop reports and other products we prepare, BLS addresses issues of both basic and applied science, such as identifying knowledge gaps and suggesting research priorities and needed investments, and the higher level policy concerns that flow from or build on the science. The Board also produces important studies on the improvement of biology education and the maintenance of a robust life sciences workforce.

The Board on Life Sciences seeks annual core support from NSF with the goal of acquiring the resources that enable the Board members and staff to perform their critical roles: overseeing the execution of on-going projects, providing guidance on future directions, evaluating emerging science and policy issues, and helping to shape BLS’s portfolio of projects in response to the evolving needs of the life sciences. For these oversight and guidance activities, the Board’s two meetings per year are of great importance, and one of these is paid for with NSF core funding. Core funding is also essential to allow the BLS staff to do the work required to develop new studies. This work requires gathering and analyzing information and negotiating with sponsors and others to define needs and develop clear statements of task. In short, core funding from NSF is crucial to maintaining BLS’s ability to respond to sponsors' needs for impartial, objective, scientifically informed advice on a diverse array of issues dealing with biological research.

BLS seeks to maintain a partnership with the NSF Biology Directorate to help address the Directorate's needs and provide assistance that is of value to NSF. BLS's contributions to this partnership have included the production of numerous requested reports and workshops on: the National Plant Genome Initiative; NEON; metagenomics; the role of theory in the life sciences; and field stations and marine labs. Although not primarily funded by NSF, the report Convergence: Facilitating Transdisciplinary Integration of Life Sciences, Physical Sciences, Engineering, and Beyond also affected NSF's thinking about its future programs: Convergence was distinguished as one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. BLS is currently working on two NSF-funded projects: a consensus report on the value and sustainability of biological collections, and a workshop on next steps for functional genomics. BLS staff are also participating in the production of a decadal report on biological physics with the Academies' Board on Physics and Astronomy with funding from NSF's program on the Physics of Living Systems in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate. BLS and the NSF Biology Directorate also have common interests in fostering the welfare of the life sciences community and promoting the highest quality of research throughout the biological sciences. National Academies’ studies overseen by BLS have drawn attention to technical, infrastructural, and educational issues affecting the life sciences. Core support for BLS is an investment that can provide returns across a wide range of NSF activities.

Below is a partial list of the reports BLS produced or collaborated on during the performance period.

  • A Decision Framework for Interventions to Increase the Persistence and Resilience of Coral Reefs (2019)
  • Understanding Northern Latitude Vegetation Greening and Browning: Proceedings of a Workshop (2019)
  • Evaluating the Taxonomic Status of the Mexican Gray Wolf and the Red Wolf (2019)
  • Management of Legionella in Water Systems (2019)
  • Fostering the Culture of Convergence in Research: Proceedings of a Workshop (2019)
  • A Research Review of Interventions to Increase the Persistence and Resilience of Coral Reefs (2018)
  • Biodefense in the Age of Synthetic Biology (2018)
  • Microbiomes of the Built Environment: A Research Agenda for Microbiology, Human Health, and Buildings (2017)
  • Undergraduate Research Experiences for STEM Students: Successes, Challenges, and Opportunities (2017)
  • Preparing for Future Products of Biotechnology (2017)
  • Gene Drives on the Horizon: Advancing Science, Navigating Uncertainty, and Aligning Research with Public Values (2016)

In addition, below is a partial list of work that BLS is currently performing:

  • Safeguarding the Bioeconomy: Finding Strategies for Understanding, Evaluating, and Protecting the Bioeconomy while Sustaining Innovation and Growth
  • Biological Collections: Their Past, Present, and Future Contributions and Options for Sustaining Them
  • Next Steps in Functional Genomics: From Genotype to Phenotype – A Workshop
  • Assistance to the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service on Taxonomic Studies of the Red Wolf: A Review of Applications to Carry Out Research and Development of a Research Strategy
  • Decadal Assessment and Outlook on Biological Physics/Physics of Living Systems
  • Understanding and Responding to Global Health Security Risks from Microbial Threats in the Arctic: A Workshop

In addition, the Board on Life Sciences was able to meet three times over the total performance period of this award.
